abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory, and
            sustainability likely, yet, institutional development
            impacts are modest. Some lessons learned are suggested as
            follows. Seeking change through consensus and participation
            contributes to the sustainability of reform efforts. The
            impact of this approach on sustainability of reforms is
            clearly visible in provider uptake of hospital payment
            reforms, and quality of care improvements. Nonetheless, the
            Ministry of Health would have benefited from technical
            support on communication, and marketing of health reforms.
            Although there is relatively good institutional capacity in
            Slovenia (information systems, human capital), the country
            had adopted a phased approach to implementing diagnostic
            related groups (DRGs). There are many benefits to this
            phased approach. It has allowed fine-tuning of health
            information systems, and training to meet the needs of DRG
            implementation, and, providers are getting used to the
            technical details of implementing DRGs. The Project was
            designed as a flexible operation with clear end-points. In
            partnership with the Bank, the country was able to adapt
            project investments to support key areas of health system
            improvement that were consistent with the policy priorities
            of the country, and for which there was support among the
            key stakeholders. The important lesson to be drawn from this
            project experience is that, in cases where there are
            significant information components, more time should be
            devoted by the Borrower and the Bank to understanding the
            legal, institutional and political constraints to
            implementing integrated information systems, and then using
            this information in the design of the information systems component.

repnme.cdata!:
Slovenia - Health Sector Management Project
            (Pase I)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Management Project
            supports the Government of Slovenia's program to
            sustain the performance of the health care system, in the
            face of adverse demographic, and epidemiological trends, and
            will be implemented by a two phase Adaptable Program Loan.
            This project, Phase I, provides health purchasing priorities
            to the Health Insurance Institute of Slovenia, through the
            adoption of improved business, and case management practices
            by the participating health providers in the pilot system.
            The components will: 1) finance technical assistance, and
            related knowledge management and training practices, in
            support of thematic working groups, through: a) the revision
            of payment mechanisms, and reimbursement models for primary,
            secondary, and tertiary care; b) the support for
            strengthening health care management, both on institutional,
            and national levels. The group will focus on the design, and
            definition of health care capacity management methodology,
            and practices, and, c) the efficiency improvement in public
            health networks; 2) establish and promote health information
            standards, for clinical, economic, statistical, and other
            information types in the sector; 3) implement health
            information systems in Slovene health sector institutions,
            linking these specific systems in an integrated health
            information system, in support of a set of multi-track
            systems implementation; and, 4) finance project management,
            and coordination.
